<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 193, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 847, 729, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 616, 240]]<|/det|>
A student measures the average speed of a cyclist in a race.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 425, 270]]<|/det|>
Which quantities must she measure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 281, 134, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 281, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the time taken for the cyclist to reach her highest speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 134, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 322, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the total distance travelled by the cyclist at her highest speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 363, 134, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 363, 855, 381]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the total distance travelled by the cyclist

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 390, 134, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 389, 866, 408]]<|/det|>
the time taken to reach her highest speed and the total distance travelled by the cyclist

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
A resultant force \(F\) accelerates a car of mass \(m\) along a straight horizontal road from rest to a speed \(v\) in time \(t\), giving it momentum \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 556, 562, 574]]<|/det|>
Which pair of relationships for this situation is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 585, 133, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 585, 316, 603]]<|/det|>
$pt = mv$ and $F = pt$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 133, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 612, 312, 630]]<|/det|>
$p = mv$ and $F = pt$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 133, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 640, 312, 657]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 666, 133, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 666, 316, 683]]<|/det|>
$p = mv t$ and $Ft = v$

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
An object is a depth \(h\) below the surface of a liquid. The pressure due to the liquid at this depth is \(p\). The gravitational field strength is \(g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 221, 401, 240]]<|/det|>
What is the density \(\rho\) of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 133, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 252, 220, 271]]<|/det|>
\(\rho = pgh\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 248, 303, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 247, 381, 271]]<|/det|>
\(\rho = \frac{pg}{h}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 247, 470, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 247, 549, 271]]<|/det|>
\(\rho = \frac{ph}{g}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 250, 636, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 248, 715, 271]]<|/det|>
\(\rho = \frac{p}{hg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 395, 339, 414]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 133, 441]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 422, 333, 441]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 390, 89]]<|/det|> Liquid evaporates from a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> What happens to the temperature of the remaining liquid and how does this temperature change affect the rate of evaporation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 475, 291]]<|/det|>
temperaturerate of evaporation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 320, 107, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 920, 354]]<|/det|> Thermal energy \(\Delta E\) is supplied to an object of mass \(m\) which does not change its state during the heating process. The temperature of the object rises by \(\Delta T\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 510, 384]]<|/det|> What is the specific heat capacity of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 396, 134, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 395, 185, 415]]<|/det|> \(\frac{\Delta E}{m\Delta T}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 395, 311, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 395, 371, 415]]<|/det|> \(m\Delta T\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 395, 470, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 395, 546, 415]]<|/det|> \(\frac{\Delta E\Delta T}{m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[611, 395, 633, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[653, 395, 703, 415]]<|/det|> \(\frac{\Delta Em}{\Delta T}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 440, 134, 459]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 456, 920, 490]]<|/det|> A room is heated by a radiator. The diagrams X and Y show two possible circulations of hot air, which heat the room. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 496, 915, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 730, 677]]<|/det|> Which diagram and reason explain the heating of the room by convection? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 646, 817]]<|/det|>
diagramreason
AXair density decreases when air is heated
BXair density increases when air is heated
CYair density decreases when air is heated
DYair density increases when air is heated

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
A student writes down some facts about two transverse waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 468, 119]]<|/det|>
Wave 1 has a frequency \(f\) and a velocity \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 794, 149]]<|/det|>
Wave 2 has four times the frequency of wave 1 and is travelling at a velocity of \(2v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 561, 180]]<|/det|>
What is the wavelength of wave 2 in terms of \(f\) and \(v\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 192, 134, 211]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 376, 618]]<|/det|>
Light travels from air into glass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 629, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
What is the relationship between the refractive index \(n\) of the glass, the angle of incidence \(i\) and the angle of refraction \(r\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 134, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 675, 165, 694]]<|/det|>
\(n = \frac{i}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 675, 298, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 675, 368, 694]]<|/det|>
\(n = \frac{r}{i}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 675, 467, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 675, 560, 694]]<|/det|>
\(n = \frac{\sin i}{\sin r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 676, 635, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 676, 675, 695]]<|/det|>
$n = \frac{\sin r}{\sin i}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

volt

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 177, 133, 196]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 220, 702, 241]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the current–voltage characteristic for a filament lamp.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 247, 616, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 890, 408]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes how the resistance of the lamp changes as the voltage increases?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 418, 133, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 418, 433, 435]]<|/det|>
The resistance decreases to zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 133, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 500, 463]]<|/det|>
The resistance decreases, but not to zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 133, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 470, 364, 488]]<|/det|>
The resistance increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 133, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 496, 428, 515]]<|/det|>
The resistance remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 540, 106, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 621, 559]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, rod R is suspended from an insulating thread.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 567, 655, 707]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 720, 873, 739]]<|/det|>
When the positively charged rod Q is brought close to rod R, rod R moves away from rod Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 564, 769]]<|/det|>
Which conclusion can be made from this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 133, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 780, 744, 797]]<|/det|>
Rod R is charged, but it is not possible to identify the sign of the charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 806, 133, 824]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 806, 438, 824]]<|/det|>
Rod R must be positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 833, 133, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 833, 445, 851]]<|/det|>
Rod R must be negatively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 860, 133, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 860, 324, 878]]<|/det|>
Rod R is uncharged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>

The completed circuit is a potential divider in which the potential difference across component Y increases when the temperature increases. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 128, 635, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 484, 314]]<|/det|> Which row shows the components X and Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 325, 668, 456]]<|/det|>
XY

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 482, 104, 500]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 482, 578, 500]]<|/det|> A piece of soft iron XY has a coil of wire wound round it. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 508, 740, 635]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 920, 677]]<|/det|> The N pole of a bar magnet is pulled away from end X which causes an induced current in the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 920, 723]]<|/det|> The magnet is now turned round so that the N pole is on the left. It is taken to the other end of the soft iron and the N pole is pushed towards end Y. A new current is induced in the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 348, 752]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 764, 134, 781]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 764, 920, 797]]<|/det|> The new induced current is in the opposite direction and causes the soft iron to attract the N pole. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 134, 821]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 804, 920, 837]]<|/det|> The new induced current is in the opposite direction and causes the soft iron to repel the N pole. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 846, 133, 863]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 846, 920, 878]]<|/det|> The new induced current is in the same direction and causes the soft iron to attract the N pole. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 886, 133, 904]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 886, 918, 903]]<|/det|> The new induced current is in the same direction and causes the soft iron to repel the N pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 771, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a wire in the magnetic field between two poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 98, 665, 237]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
The current in the wire repeatedly changes between a constant value in one direction and a constant value in the opposite direction, as shown in the graph.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 295, 707, 421]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 369, 456]]<|/det|>
What is the effect on the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 465, 134, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 465, 824, 485]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire alternates between one direction and the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 133, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 490, 598, 510]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire is constant in size and direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 517, 133, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 517, 544, 536]]<|/det|>
There is no force acting on the wire at any time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 133, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 543, 641, 562]]<|/det|>
There is only a force on the wire when the current reverses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 588, 106, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 588, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
A transformer has \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) turns on its primary coil and \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) turns on its secondary coil. The voltage across the primary coil is \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) and the voltage across the secondary coil is \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 632, 571, 652]]<|/det|>
What is the relationship between these four quantities?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 133, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 661, 293, 680]]<|/det|>
\(V_{\mathrm{p}}\times V_{\mathrm{s}} = N_{\mathrm{p}}\times N_{\mathrm{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 133, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 688, 225, 727]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = \frac{N_{\mathrm{p}}}{N_{\mathrm{s}}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 133, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 734, 225, 772]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = \frac{N_{\mathrm{s}}}{N_{\mathrm{p}}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 788, 133, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 784, 260, 821]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = N_{\mathrm{p}}\times N_{\mathrm{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 902, 89]]<|/det|> A magnesium ion has a double positive charge and a chloride ion has a single negative charge. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 348, 119]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 628, 147]]<|/det|> A chlorine atom gains an electron to form the chloride ion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 158, 131, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 157, 603, 175]]<|/det|> A chlorine atom loses a proton to form the chloride ion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 690, 200]]<|/det|> A magnesium atom loses an electron to form the magnesium ion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 707, 225]]<|/det|> A magnesium atom gains two electrons to form the magnesium ion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 648, 272]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes an example of radioactive decay? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 662, 429]]<|/det|>
original nucleusemissionchange or no change of element
Astableγchange of element
Bunstableαchange of element
Cunstableαno change of element
Dunstableβno change of element

count rate counts/s400260170115
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 641, 490, 658]]<|/det|> What is the background radiation count rate? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 131, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 255, 688]]<|/det|> 12 counts/ s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 131, 714]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 696, 255, 714]]<|/det|> 15 counts/ s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 723, 131, 740]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 723, 255, 740]]<|/det|> 20 counts/ s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 131, 766]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 750, 255, 766]]<|/det|> 30 counts/ s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 794, 104, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 794, 514, 811]]<|/det|> What happens in the process of nuclear fission? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 821, 131, 839]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 430, 839]]<|/det|> Electrons are added to a nucleus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 848, 131, 866]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 848, 472, 866]]<|/det|> Electrons are removed from a nucleus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 875, 131, 892]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 875, 400, 892]]<|/det|> The nucleus of an atom splits. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 901, 131, 919]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 901, 415, 919]]<|/det|> Two atomic nuclei join together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 705, 91]]<|/det|>
The time taken for the Earth to orbit the Sun is approximately 365 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 697, 122]]<|/det|>
The average radius of the Earth's orbit around the Sun is \(1.5 \times 10^{8} \text{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 507, 152]]<|/det|>
What is the average orbital speed of the Earth?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 133, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 215, 179]]<|/det|>
30 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 189, 133, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 188, 268, 207]]<|/det|>
\(4.8 \times 10^{3} \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 216, 133, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 215, 268, 234]]<|/det|>
\(3.0 \times 10^{4} \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 242, 133, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 242, 275, 261]]<|/det|>
\(4.1 \times 10^{10} \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 287, 106, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 715, 305]]<|/det|>
The Sun transfers energy to the Earth through electromagnetic radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 316, 908, 336]]<|/det|>
What are two of the parts of the electromagnetic spectrum to which most of the energy belongs?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 133, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 345, 353, 364]]<|/det|>
gamma rays and X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 131, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 371, 428, 390]]<|/det|>
infrared radiation and visible light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 133, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 397, 386, 416]]<|/det|>
microwaves and visible light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 133, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 422, 395, 441]]<|/det|>
radio waves and microwaves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 467, 106, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 467, 440, 486]]<|/det|>
How does the Sun produce its energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 133, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 496, 344, 515]]<|/det|>
by the fission of helium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 133, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 368, 542]]<|/det|>
by the fission of hydrogen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 133, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 339, 567]]<|/det|>
by the fusion of helium

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 133, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 364, 593]]<|/det|>
by the fusion of hydrogen
